abstracts.cdata!:
The Municipal Services Project in
            Bangladesh had an outcomes rating of satisfactory.  The risk
            to development outcome was moderate.  Bank performance was
            rated as moderately satisfactory and borrower performance
            was satisfactory.  The lessons learned are as follows: (1)
            Allow sufficient time for a new institution to be
            established, especially when it accompanies a major policy
            reform. (2) The MDF model in supporting ULB infrastructure
            investments was effective and should be continued with
            stronger technical support. (3) Introducing a municipal fund
            where there are small cities with weak financial systems
            requires realistic eligibility criteria for participating
            municipalities and ample institutional capacity building to
            allow them to participate and sustain their investments. (4)
            Closer coordination between BMDF and LGED in providing
            institutional strengthening and technical support would
            strengthen BMDF operations. (5) The MSU was an effective
            vehicle for delivering and coordinating technical and
            institutional support to municipalities assisted by the
            World Bank and other donors. (6) Including a disaster risk
            management (or contingent emergency response) component in
            projects where there is a high risk of flooding and other
            natural disasters facilitates an emergency response. (7)
            Using the Participatory and Partnership Approach (PPA) built
            project ownership.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Municipal Services Project :
            additional financing

abstracts.cdata!:
This project paper seeks the approval of
            the Executive Directors to provide an additional credit to
            the Municipal Services Project. The additional credit will
            help finance the scaling up of improvements in urban
            infrastructure and the municipal financial and management
            capacity. The project has so far financed the rehabilitation
            or construction of urban infrastructure in about 130
            municipalities (and the repair and rehabilitation of
            flood-damaged infrastructure in 195 towns), as well as a
            capacity strengthening program of 92 municipalities. These
            activities have been carried out well and resulted in
            significant benefits as well as strong demand for additional
            support. The additional credit will help extend the partial
            financing of urban infrastructure improvements to some 170
            towns, ' and extend the municipal capacity
            strengthening program to about 142 municipalities, out of
            315 urban local bodies (ULBs) of Bangladesh. Further, the
            additional financing will support the development of a next
            generation of urban improvement programs. The additional
            financing will be the second one to help scale up the core
            components of the project. In recognition of the good early
            implementation record under the project, an additional
            financing of $25 million was approved in 2008 to help
            rehabilitate the damages to urban infrastructure as a part
            of the Emergency 2007 Flood Restoration and Recovery
            Assistance Program.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Emergency 2007 Flood
            Restoration and Recovery Assistance Program (FRRAP)

abstracts.cdata!:
This project paper on the Emergency 2007
            Flood Restoration and Recovery Assistance Program (FRRAP) of
            Bangladesh seeks the restructuring of seven projects to
            three of the projects [Social Investment Social Investment
            Program Project (Cr. 3740), Municipal  Services Project (Cr.
            3177) and Rural Transport Improvement Project (Cr. 3791)].
            The additional financing will be used to support the
            Emergency 2007 Flood Restoration and Recovery Assistance
            Program (2007 FRRAP) in Bangladesh. The restructuring of
            above-referenced projects, including the additional
            financing, will form part of the larger IDA support package
            for 2007 FRRAP, which also includes funding embedded in the
            ongoing projects mentioned above and two other credits
            (Health, Nutrition and Population Sector Program, Cr.4052,
            and Primary Education Program 11, Cr 3857. The credit
            closing dates of three Credits (Cr. 3177, Cr. 3791 and Cr.
            3740) will be extended to June 30, 2011. The Emergency 2007
            FRRAP consists of two components: (A) infrastructure
            rehabilitation covering (i) rehabilitation of secondary,
            regional, and rural roads, (ii) reconstruction of bridges
            and culverts (iii) rehabilitation of urban roads, bridges
            and culverts, and drainage facilities in municipalities,
            (iv) rehabilitation of health facilities, (v) rehabilitation
            of flood embankments, flood control and drainage, and
            irrigation schemes, (vi) rehabilitation of water supply and
            sanitation facilities, and (B) livelihood restoration
            through low interest loans and community projects. The flood
            restoration works will support sectors where the Bank is
            currently financing regular investments. Concerned
            Government of Bangladesh (GOB) line ministries and
            departments will be accountable for their respective
            infrastructure rehabilitation within the framework of
            ongoing projects. This ensures overall rapid and effective
            implementation without major amendments to each project design.
